title: Is the person who writes the president’s speeches, essentially telling him what to say? - Quora
tags: Presidents of the United States of America

response.answer_text: No. A speech writer knows pretty much what the president (or presidential candidate) wants to say, and will often have a list of main topics and/or points. By the time someone has won the presidency, they will have a team of speech writers. The team will usually put together an outline or a draft, and then see what the president (or candidate) thinks of it, then produce a complete draft for the president (or candidate) to read through. My limited experience is that the read-through will include parts of the speech (maybe the whole thing) spoken aloud, so see if the tone works, and the overall rhythm is comfortable for the speaker. Peggy Noonan apparently had Ronald Reagan’s “voice” down pat. Depending on the venue, the topic, and the time allowed, there may be some cutting necessary. Despite all that, some presidents (or presidential candidates) just can’t deliver a speech well. Walter Mondale comes to mind. And the current POTUS likes to depart from a text, because he seems to feel he can read the crowd, and the specific contents of much of the speech are not that important. That leads to some objectively bad deliveries, but his fans seem not to care.

Yes and No. Every President has a speech writer, they don’t necessarily tell him what to think, but they tend to know what the sentiment or message is that the President wishes to talk about and create the speech for him/her- so on one hand, they probably write more eloquently than the President would think to say spontaneously - Obama for instance was not very good at speaking extemporaneously - lots of ums and ahs and mouth clicking; whereas Trump is a bit better at extemporaneous, but repeats certain phrases and expressions a lot and many things are ‘great’. It’s hard to speak in front of a large number of people and/or the press and always be erudite and on top of your game. They have many different events and issues to attend to, so speech writing if they did it themselves could end up taking all their time, so it helps to have people who know how they think about issues and what they wish to express to do it for them.

Absolutely not. The speech writer puts what the President wants to say in prose. The writer is skilled at inciting people by how his words are structured. JFK is known for having said, “Ask not what your country can do for you, but what do can do for your country.” RFK - “Some people see thing as they are and ask why. I see things that aren’t, and ask why not.” Being able to put words together that catches the imagination is a gift. These speech writers have an idea or outline of the President’s agenda. It is his job to put words together to convey this to the American public, as the President attends to other details. Often their are numerous speech writers as the President can give numerous speeches in a single day to different groups and rallies. It take time to write a speech, often time the President doesn’t have with his busy schedule. Speech writers often have to review facts and do hours of research, that relate to the audience they are trying to connect with. How well they write, and the President can deliver, does a lot to create a positive image of the President. The President also has the option of editing and the ability to ad lib. President Ronald Reagan went to Berlin, and mentioned he would like to make a statement about the Soviets removing the Berlin Wall. All his advisers cautioned against the President about making such a statement, so the speechwriters left this out. Reagan was overlooking the West German crowd standing in front of the wall, was overcome, and stated, “Mr. Gorbachev, tear down this wall!” This was one of President’s most memorial lines he ever spoke as President. So in the final saying of words uttered, the President came say anything he wants.

Two types of speeches. In the one kind, wherein it is written an apologia of sorts, for instance, his speeches to the country about how sorry he is for the latest racist mass murder. yes indeed, those speechwriters are telling him what to say. Trump doesn’t have the words himself for these. But in the other kind, he is given notes from the voter samplings of new or tried and true epithets conjured for these folks, as test groups, to see if they’re still valuable. And then he tries them out in his stand-up routines to see what happens. He may already have something in the prompter, but he is known for going off script, to the great amazement and delight of his cult. So to be brief, in the one kind he is told what to say, and in the other, he is telling others what to say.

No, not usually; we speechwriters only wish we had that much power. What we do is get to know our principal (client) as well as we can, try to capture his or her voice, find out what he or she wants to say, and then say it as compellingly as possible. It is usually a collaborative effort; often we can be very helpful in pulling stories from the client that make the subject vivid and real, or finding the perfect detail or turn of phrase to illustrate a point. Occasionally it is up to the speechwriter to come up with the appropriate thing for a President to say, such as when William Safire was given the unenviable task of preparing remarks for President Nixon in case the Apollo 11 mission failed. And it does seem as if the speechwriters for the current occupant of the Oval Office are sometimes trying to tell him what to say, as with the remarks after the recent shootings. It very clear when he is reading something off a teleprompter or when he is speaking off the cuff, and the messages are often diametrically different. But usually speechwriter and client are on the same page. Thanks for asking.

Not traditionally. Historically, the speech writer’s job was to capture the office holder’s voice, subject to review and rewriting. By contrast, “Trump” is a chorus. We know that he doesn’t write all of his own tweets. He may not write any of them. He may not even approve them. We also know that he’s drugged for his big addresses because Ronnie Jackson revealed it. The difference between those voices is like night and day. And, we don’t know which, if any of them, belong to him. In other words, the fairest answer is probably, “We don’t know.”

Not really. There are other people who tell the speech writers what is to go into the speech. I don’t watch political speeches so I don’t know this for certain. In Fletcher Prouty’s book he says one night Carter started to go off script and they literally pulled the plug on him. They put up the stand-by technical difficulties sign while somebody took Carter into a side room and explained the facts of life to him. When he came back, he stuck to the script. One of the great ironies in this is that the more the propaganda apparatus began to describe the president as “the most powerful man in the western world”, the less power he actually had.

When Trump has to speak at a formal occasion, he uses speechwriters (more than one). All presidents use speech writers, but presidents use what they write as a guide, and make changes, and refine the speech and they make sure it reflects their position accurately. Trump reads off the teleprompter, and the talking points aren’t his. They are graceful remarks about current events, such as the shooting in El Paso. In this case, his writers were jumping through hoops to make sure Trump came across as caring and human, a tall order. Trump’s speech following that tragedy, echoed the views of concerned voters who are upset at the carnage. A couple of days later, he was walking all that back as he again incited his followers to trash minorities. He knows he has to pretend he cares and for a few minutes after a tragedy, he tries to do this. If you want to know what he really thinks, just follow his tweets — totally hateful, totally deranged.

Yes and no. A good speech writer will have a idea what the president wants to talk about and needs to talk about at that speech and their job isn’t to put words in the presidents mouth but to I hope the president keep on subject. Presidents often have a lot to do and this is a way to help keep the president focused on more important matters than exactly how they’re going to wear their speech, and we have somebody who helps keep the president on. When he makes that speech and make sure it’s worded in such a way That it’s not damaging.

No. The speech writer is telling him how to say it. But Presidents can do what ever they want with the speeches. One of the most famous things a President has ever said is when Ronald Reagan said, “ Mr. Gorbachev, tear down that wall.” It was not in the speech that was written for him, but he said it anyway. His advisors had told him it was too inflammatory.

Not exactly. It’s more like the speechwriter crafts into writing intended for speech the thoughts the president wants to convey. Without a good speechwriter—probably a team of speech writers—the speeches of a guy like Donald Trump would be pure nonsense, and we get quite enough nonsense from him as it is.

I don’t believe any president gives his speech writer that much latitude. Presidents, after all, are the chief strategists of foreign and domestic policy. The speech writers guide the president in HOW to say it. How is as important as WHAT in a a President’s speech

My friend has a brother who was a speech writer.He told us that the process is collaborative and the writer spends a lot of time listening to and refining what the politician wants to say.The current Occupant clearly attempts the process but frequently abandons it in favor of going with his own brilliant ideas.
Usually the President will work with the speech writers or at least give them an idea of what they want to say. The President can read it or make changes. That’s my understanding

No, the president decides what the speech’s content should be, and the speechwriters take that direction, and put it into words that will sound good, and hopefully evoke the desired response from the audience.

No. The President has his agenda and they discuss it daily with Senior Staff, which includes Communications Director ( speechwriters) and they hone his message for him. The President reads it and tweaks it for the rewrite.
Not really, speechwriters actually tailor their speeches to the person they’re writing for, and generally a conscientiousness President will have changes to make and alter the speech.
